pageProps.contentHtml:
mean value property, Morera's theorem

Let D\DD be the open unit disc and μ\muμ be the Lebesgue measure on D\DD. Let HHH be the subspace of L2(D,μ)L^2\p{\D, \mu}L2(D,μ) consisting of holomorphic functions. Show that HHH is complete.
Solution.

L2(D,μ)L^2\p{\D, \mu}L2(D,μ) is itself complete, so it suffices to show that HHH is closed in L2(D,μ)L^2\p{\D, \mu}L2(D,μ).

Let {fn}n⊆H\set{f_n}_n \subseteq H{fn​}n​⊆H be a sequence converging to f∈L2(D,μ)f \in L^2\p{\D, \mu}f∈L2(D,μ). Let z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D and 0<r<R0 < r < R0<r<R small enough so that B(z,R)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{z, R}} \subseteq \DB(z,R)​⊆D. Then by the mean value property,

fn(z)−fm(z)=12π∫02πfn(z+reiθ)−fm(z+reiθ) dz=12π∫02πfn(z+reiθ)−fm(z+reiθ) dθ.\begin{aligned} f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z} &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f_n\p{z + re^{i\theta}} - f_m\p{z + re^{i\theta}} \,\diff{z} \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f_n\p{z + re^{i\theta}} - f_m\p{z + re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta. \end{aligned}fn​(z)−fm​(z)​=2π1​∫02π​fn​(z+reiθ)−fm​(z+reiθ)dz=2π1​∫02π​fn​(z+reiθ)−fm​(z+reiθ)dθ.​

Multiplying both sides by 2r2r2r and integrating over [0,R]\br{0, R}[0,R], we get

2r(fn(z)−fm(z))=1π∫02πr(fn(z+reiθ)−fm(z+reiθ)) dθ  ⟹  R2(fn(z)−fm(z))=1π∫02πfn(z)−fm(z) dμ  ⟹  fn(z)−fm(z)=1πR2∫B(z,R)fn(z)−fm(z) dμ.\begin{aligned} 2r\p{f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z}} &= \frac{1}{\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} r\p{f_n\p{z + re^{i\theta}} - f_m\p{z + re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \\ \implies R^2\p{f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z}} &= \frac{1}{\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z} \,\diff\mu \\ \implies f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z} &= \frac{1}{\pi R^2} \int_{B\p{z,R}} f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z} \,\diff\mu. \end{aligned}2r(fn​(z)−fm​(z))⟹R2(fn​(z)−fm​(z))⟹fn​(z)−fm​(z)​=π1​∫02π​r(fn​(z+reiθ)−fm​(z+reiθ))dθ=π1​∫02π​fn​(z)−fm​(z)dμ=πR21​∫B(z,R)​fn​(z)−fm​(z)dμ.​

Now we may apply the triangle inequality along with Cauchy-Schwarz:

∣fn(z)−fm(z)∣≤1πR2∫B(z,R)∣fn(z)−fm(z)∣ dμ≤(μ(B(z,R)))1/2πR2∥fn−fm∥2≤(μ(B(z,R)))1/2πR2∥fn−fm∥2\begin{aligned} \abs{f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z}} &\leq \frac{1}{\pi R^2} \int_{B\p{z,R}} \abs{f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z}} \,\diff\mu \\ &\leq \frac{\p{\mu\p{B\p{z, R}}}^{1/2}}{\pi R^2} \norm{f_n - f_m}_2 \\ &\leq \frac{\p{\mu\p{B\p{z, R}}}^{1/2}}{\pi R^2} \norm{f_n - f_m}_2 \end{aligned}∣fn​(z)−fm​(z)∣​≤πR21​∫B(z,R)​∣fn​(z)−fm​(z)∣dμ≤πR2(μ(B(z,R)))1/2​∥fn​−fm​∥2​≤πR2(μ(B(z,R)))1/2​∥fn​−fm​∥2​​

We will show that {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is locally uniformly Cauchy: Let 0<R<10 < R < 10<R<1 and let 0<δ<dist⁡(B(0,R)‾,Dc)0 < \delta < \operatorname{dist}\p{\cl{B\p{0, R}}, \D^\comp}0<δ<dist(B(0,R)​,Dc). This is positive since it is the distance between two closed, disjoint sets. Thus, for any z∈B(0,R)z \in B\p{0, R}z∈B(0,R) we have that B(z,δ)⊆B(0,R+δ)‾⊆DB\p{z, \delta} \subseteq \cl{B\p{0, R + \delta}} \subseteq \DB(z,δ)⊆B(0,R+δ)​⊆D, and so

∣fn(z)−fm(z)∣≤(μ(B(z,δ)))1/2πδ2∥fn−fm∥2≤(μ(B(0,R)))1/2πδ2∥fn−fm∥2=CR∥fn−fm∥2,\begin{aligned} \abs{f_n\p{z} - f_m\p{z}} &\leq \frac{\p{\mu\p{B\p{z, \delta}}}^{1/2}}{\pi \delta^2} \norm{f_n - f_m}_2 \\ &\leq \frac{\p{\mu\p{B\p{0, R}}}^{1/2}}{\pi \delta^2} \norm{f_n - f_m}_2 \\ &= C_R \norm{f_n - f_m}_2, \end{aligned}∣fn​(z)−fm​(z)∣​≤πδ2(μ(B(z,δ)))1/2​∥fn​−fm​∥2​≤πδ2(μ(B(0,R)))1/2​∥fn​−fm​∥2​=CR​∥fn​−fm​∥2​,​

and notice that CRC_RCR​ is independent of zzz. Thus, since {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is Cauchy in L2(D,μ)L^2\p{\D, \mu}L2(D,μ), it follows that {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is uniformly Cauchy on B(0,R)‾\cl{B\p{0, R}}B(0,R)​. Since RRR was arbitrary, it follows that {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is uniformly Cauchy on any compact set, so by completeness, there exists g ⁣:D→C\func{g}{\D}{\C}g:D→C such that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f uniformly on compact sets.

By assumption, fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f in L2(D,μ)L^2\p{\D, \mu}L2(D,μ), so there exists a subsequence which converges pointwise to fff almost everywhere. Since fn→gf_n \to gfn​→g pointwise, it follows that g=fg = fg=f almost everywhere, so the pointwise limit is the same thing as the L2(D,μ)L^2\p{\D, \mu}L2(D,μ) limit.

Finally, since fnf_nfn​ is holomorphic, it is continuous, which means that fff is continuous as well. Hence, we may apply Morera's theorem. By uniform convergence on compact sets, we get for any square ∂R\partial R∂R in D\DD that

0=lim⁡n→∞∫∂Rfn(z) dz=∫∂Rf(z) dz,0 = \lim_{n\to\infty} \int_{\partial R} f_n\p{z} \,\diff{z} = \int_{\partial R} f\p{z} \,\diff{z},0=n→∞lim​∫∂R​fn​(z)dz=∫∂R​f(z)dz,

so f∈Hf \in Hf∈H. Consequently, HHH is closed, hence complete.
